title: 106_hr942
content: The "Broadcast Ownership for the 21st Century Act" amends the Communications Act of 1934 by revising duopoly rules. The "Broadcast Ownership for the 21st Century Act" amends duopoly rules by allowing ownership of two stations with overlapping coverage contours in separate television markets or two television stations within the same market if one is a UHF station. It also protects existing local marketing agreements between two broadcast television stations in the same market. The Broadcast Ownership for the 21st Century Act exempts stations in the same television market signed before its enactment from the television duopoly rule. The Commission may allow ownership of two VHF television stations in the same market under certain circumstances. The Broadcast Ownership for the 21st Century Act exempts stations in the same television market from the television duopoly rule. The Commission may permit ownership of two VHF television stations in the same market if it does not harm competition or media diversity. SEC. 3. CROSS-OWNERSHIP LIMITATIONS. The Federal Communications Commission is required to make rule changes to eliminate restrictions on granting or renewing broadcast station licenses based on ownership of a daily newspaper and to remove the one-to-a-market rule. Additionally, the Commission must preserve the cognizable interest rule while making these modifications. The Commission will not consider a minority voting stock interest as significant if one holder owns over 50% of the voting stock. Cable cross-ownership limitations are also addressed in the Communications Act of 1934. The Federal Communications Commission will revise regulations to allow television broadcast stations to affiliate with entities maintaining multiple networks, unless those networks were offering interconnected program services for 15 hours or more per day before February 8, 1996. The Federal Communications Commission will revise regulations to allow television broadcast stations to affiliate with entities maintaining multiple networks, unless those networks were offering interconnected program services for 15 hours or more per week to at least 25 affiliated television licensees in 10 or more States. The deadline for completing all necessary actions for the modifications required by this section is 90 days after the date of enactment of this Act. SEC. 4 amends the Telecommunications Act of 1996 to increase the ownership limit to 45 percent. The Federal Communications Commission must implement this change within 90 days. SEC. 5 addresses reciprocal treatment of foreign ownership restrictions. Subsection (b) of section 310 of the Communications Act of 1934 is amended to restrict foreign ownership of broadcast or common carrier licenses. No licenses shall be granted to aliens, foreign corporations, or corporations with more than one-fifth of capital stock owned by aliens. The Communications Act of 1934 restricts foreign ownership of broadcast or common carrier licenses, prohibiting voting or ownership by aliens, foreign governments, or corporations organized under foreign laws. This includes any corporation controlled by another corporation with significant foreign ownership. The Communications Act of 1934 prohibits foreign ownership of broadcast or common carrier licenses, including voting or ownership by aliens, foreign governments, or corporations organized under foreign laws. The Act also restricts licenses if the public interest is not served by granting or revoking them. Additionally, reciprocal treatment for broadcast station licenses is required if the foreign country allows licenses to be held by US persons or corporations. The Communications Act of 1934 prohibits foreign ownership of broadcast licenses, including voting or ownership by aliens, foreign governments, or foreign corporations. The Act also requires reciprocal treatment for broadcast station licenses if the foreign country allows licenses to be held by US persons or corporations. If a corporation seeking a broadcast station license is controlled by US persons, the Commission may allow foreign ownership of a portion of the capital stock. The FCC may permit foreign ownership of a portion of the capital stock of a corporation holding a broadcast station license in a foreign country, as long as the voting stock ownership does not exceed 40 percent. The term "United States person" refers to any corporation organized under US laws. The FCC allows foreign ownership of a portion of a broadcast station license-holding corporation in a foreign country, with voting stock ownership capped at 40 percent. A "United States person" includes corporations organized under US laws, US citizens, US governments, or their representatives.
